Articles.Content:
Title: It's the heart of Kerbin a black hole?

Considering the surface gravity is 9.8 m/s and the radius of Kerbin is about 300km, just imagine the density.

Imagine the density of the core... Imagine the gravity of the core... Imagine the black hole sucking in the whole of kerbin
Every planet in the game is superdense. The game is scaled such the spaceflight isn't a huge chore. If you prefer a more realistic solar system, there are mods that can help.
Kerbin's core is the head of the dumbest person you know.
Some fast math shows a density of approximately 58Ã¢â‚¬â€°485g/cm3. That's about 26 times as dense as the densest element in our universe!

...the radius of Kerbin is about 300km, just imagine the density.

Radius of 600km, diameter of 1200km; not diameter of 600km
accuracy could be as important as the concept in itself (cf. xx xxx time thread)
If any of you guys every had the Kore Kraken strike, then you will know that every planet and moon in ksp has a huge black hole in them.

To be a black hole Kerbin's mass would have to be contained within approximately 8*10^-5 meters. Or approximately .08 millimeters. Unless it's just a point mass with a shell this is unlikely, thus there is no black hole at the heart of Kerbin.
